@FLMakeupGirl •It will improve the efficiency for stores to stock shelves allowing them to fit more boxes on shelf
•Transportation costs are surging, this change allows more efficient truck loading with consistent sizing leading to fewer trucks on the road and fewer gallons of fuel used TY!

•Big G Cereal portfolio had inconsistent sizing across brands – this change allows for consistency and standardization across the portfolio – making it easier for shoppers to distinguish between sizes on shelf

@DavidMo66984563 You can read more about our palm oil sourcing on our website https://t.co/atvWDu3ry4.

@DavidMo66984563 To help ensure our purchases do not contribute to deforestation of the world’s rainforests or negatively impact the communities that depend on them, we sourced 100 percent of our palm oil from responsible and sustainable sources by 2016.
@DavidMo66984563 And despite being a highly productive crop that can offer a path out of poverty, unsustainable palm oil production practices can also threaten the rights of indigenous peoples.
@DavidMo66984563 Deforestation is a major contributor to global climate change, accounting for an estimated 15 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions.

@DavidMo66984563 We are concerned about the role of palm oil expansion in the deforestation of the world’s rainforests and about the impact of deforestation on biodiversity, endangered species, and the broader environment.
@DavidMo66984563 Nevertheless, we recognize that responsible users of even small amounts of ingredients can impact issues via principled purchasing practices.

@DavidMo66984563 Hi David! General Mills is committed to sourcing palm oil in a socially and environmentally responsible manner.
General Mills is a relatively minor user of palm oil.

@noagediet Safe food is, and always has been, our number one priority. Global food and safety regulatory bodies including the FDA (Food & Drug Administration) and the WHO (World Health Organization) have also verified their safety. For more facts on GMOs, please visit this page:

@noagediet If a food or beverage product sold in the U.S. lists corn, soy, canola or sugar as an ingredient - and if the product is not organic - it likely contains GMOs. GMOs are safe – we would not use them if we thought otherwise.

@GaiaBerretta You can read more about our palm oil sourcing on our website here: https://t.co/hZvNVSf1d0 . Your views are important to us.

@GaiaBerretta To help ensure our purchases do not contribute to deforestation of the world’s rainforests or negatively impact the communities that depend on them, we sourced 100 percent of our palm oil from responsible and sustainable sources by 2016.
@GaiaBerretta And despite being a highly productive crop that can offer a path out of poverty, unsustainable palm oil production practices can also threaten the rights of indigenous peoples.
@GaiaBerretta Deforestation is a major contributor to global climate change, accounting for an estimated 15 percent of global greenhouse gas emissions.

@GaiaBerretta We are concerned about the role of palm oil expansion in the deforestation of the world’s rainforests and about the impact of deforestation on biodiversity, endangered species, and the broader environment.
@GaiaBerretta Nevertheless, we recognize that responsible users of even small amounts of ingredients can impact issues via principled purchasing practices.
@GaiaBerretta General Mills is committed to sourcing palm oil in a socially and environmentally responsible manner. General Mills is a relatively minor user of palm oil.

@theatomicmom We appreciate your question and understand your concern. We are confident in our labeling practices. If there is any risk of an allergen present in one of our products, it will be listed in the Contains or May Contains statements on the product package. Have a great day!

@theatomicmom When changes are made we make several efforts to inform the consumer. In all cases we would change the ingredient listing. Again, if there is any risk, we would cross label where we feel the risk is great that the allergen may carry over to be present in the non-allergenic food.

@theatomicmom If there is any risk that one of the Top 8 Allergens, (as well as sesame, sunflower, and mollusks) would be present in one of our products, it would be listed in BOLD in the ‘May Contains’ statement under the Ingredient Listing. If it is NOT listed, it is not present.

@theatomicmom If one of our products contains any of the top 8 allergens, or if there's a potential of carryover of material that could elicit an allergic response, the allergen of concern will be listed in bold in the "Contains" or “May Contains” statement just below the list of ingredients.

@earth_dave Because so many U.S. farmers use GM seed to grow certain crops, if an American food or beverage product lists corn, soy, canola, cottonseed or beet sugar as an ingredient – and it is not organic – it likely contains GMOs.

@earth_dave Biotech seeds have been approved by global food safety agencies and widely used by farmers in food crops for almost 20 years. In the United States today, 70 percent of foods on grocery store shelves or in restaurants likely contain GM ingredients.

@earth_dave Thank you for your reply, Dave! Products often contain GM ingredients in the U.S., not because companies seek to use GM ingredients, but because GM crops are so prevalent in the U.S. food supply.

@earth_dave Hi Dave! We offer our consumers organic products in most of our major categories as a non-GMO choice. We suggest you try Annie's Granola Bars or Cascadian Farm Chewy Granola bars; they are certified Organic.

@ExcuseMyFancy Actually, the trisodium phosphate does its work in the dough stage, and then mostly dissolves as the dough is made into cereal.  As a result, those who eat cereals consume very little – if any – TSP.

@ExcuseMyFancy Trisodium phosphate is a water-soluble salt.  It is used in a wide variety of food products, and is approved as safe by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The very small amounts of trisodium phosphate used in a cereal product helps adjust the acidity of the cereal dough.
